column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat|salience|identity|centering
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent

#Summary1=(human1) Attorney Eric Levi, representing appellant Darnell Hurt before Chief Justice Kennedy and the Court, argues that his client, charged for felonious assault and felony murder, should not be retried, since a prior jury already applied a provocation mitigator for voluntary manslaughter to him, and therefore effectively acquitted him of being prosecuted based on 'double jeopardy'.

#Summary2=(claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) Attorney Eric Levi argues before the Court that collateral estoppel should prevent his client Darnell Hurt from being retried for murder charges since a jury previously found in his favor regarding provocation mitigators in a voluntary manslaughter case.

#Summary3=(gpt4o) Eric Levi argues that under collateral estoppel and double jeopardy principles, Darnell Hurt should not face retrial for felony murder due to a previous jury finding a provocation mitigator, which acts as an affirmative defense, and contends the Ohio court should rule before retrial to prevent Hurt from facing the same charges again.

#Summary4=(Meta-Llama-3-8B-Instruct) Eric Levi argues that collateral estoppel prevents retrial of Darnell Hurt, whose prior jury found provocation mitigators, and that this issue is ripe for ruling prior to a new trial.

#Summary5=(Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct) Appellant Darnell Hurt's legal team argues that the previous jury's finding regarding the provocation mitigator for voluntary manslaughter should be binding due to collateral estoppel, preventing the need to re-prove the same mitigating circumstances in a retrial for additional charges.
#Text=Chief Justice Kennedy and may it please the Court .
#Text=My name is Eric Levi and I 'm arguing for appellant Darnell Hurt .
#Text=Uh , attorney John Martin will be arguing the rebuttal , and we 'd reserve five minutes of time .
#Text=Your honors , if I may , I 'd like to start by addressing proposition of law number three .
#Text=In proposition of law number three , we have an ultimate finding of fact which was resolved in favor of Darnell Hurt .
#Text=This finding of fact was in regard to a provocation mitigator , um , on the voluntary manslaughter charge .

#Text=Darnell Hurt had asked for the provocation mitiger- mitigator to apply to all offenses which he was charged , which includes the felonious assault , and indirectly then he also requested it , um , for the felony murder charge as well .
#Text=The provocation mitigator is identical for the voluntary manslaughter as well as the felonious assaults and felony murder .

#Text=We believe that on retrial , collateral estoppel would prevent retrial without regard for the jury 's prior finding in Hurt 's favor , that ther- that the provocation mitigator existed , that he was acting under serious provocation .

#Text=In fact , at the trial , the State , and it can be found in the transcript at pages 774 and 775 , admitted as much and conceded so in its closing argument by stating to the jury that the victim was coming into this apartment .
#Text=He was coming in hot and he pulled out his firearm .
#Text=And here comes Melvin Dobson arriving at the scene to the rescue of his daughter .
#Text=And that incenses him , Hurt , to the point where he uses deadly force .
#Text=And then they said , if you apply all the factors , that 's voluntary manslaughter .
#Text=That 's where this count applies .
#Text=The State of Ohio had then directed the jury to find these provocation mitigators , which it did .

#Text=In looking at Green versus United States and the courts , the high court out of the state of Texas and the federal circuits in Kennedy versus Washington on this constitutional issue , I believe that the authority uh exists to find that collateral estoppel would preclude the defendant from having to prove these mitigators a second time to a different jury because he preserved the issue by requesting the jury instruction for the mitigators on all of the applicable counts , and he did n't request that the jury -- or concede to permit the jury to be discharged without considering those mitigators , when the jury did n't consider them and the additional counts , it acted almost as an applied acquittal or an applied um finding towards this affirmative defense .
#Text=The high court in Texas in ex parte Jimmy Dean Watkins agreed with that .
#Text=And it indicated that in any additional trial , once a jury finds those provocation mitigators , that it ca n't be required to find them again .

#Text=Additionally , in the Kennedy versus Washington uh matter , the Federal Circuit Court stated that the Green versus United States implied acquittal would generally apply in cases where the provocation mitigator was at issue .
#Text=It was addressed and argued by both sides , and the jury was asked to make a finding .
#Text=Here the jury made the finding .
#Text=It made a specific finding for the provocation mitigator .
#Text=And while it did n't find it on each and every specific count , that was solely because the instruction was n't given even though requested .
#Text=Counsel , um , should n't the arguments related to Proposition three B , are they ripe for for ruling ?
#Text=Should n't these arguments be made at the -- at the trial court , given the fact that this was remanded ?
#Text=So , Your Honor , this was remanded for a retrial and it 's remanded on the grounds of double jeopardy through the prong of collateral estoppel .

#Text=And under double jeopardy , not only is an individual precluded from being convicted twice , or to stand trial twice for an offense , he was already acquitted of , he 's also precluded from having to actually stand trial to go back to trial for a second time when the acquittal was already made .
#Text=In this case , it 's a finding of fact under collateral estoppel , but it amounts to an affirmative defense to acquit him of the murder , essentially .

#Text=Um , so where the murderer was already negated by the findings for the -- the mitigators , we believe that it is ripe at this point um prior to new trial , that this court rule on this and preclude um the trial court from requiring that he face the murder charges again .
#Text=What about the other issues ?
#Text=I mean , how can they be ripe ?
#Text=The proble- , uh , excuse me , the uh -- the self defense issues uh we believe are ripe first and foremost in proposition .
